urls.title: Climate crisis hitting 'worst case scenario', warns Environment Agency head
urls.description: The climate emergency is already hitting ‚Äúworst case scenario‚Äù levels that if left unchecked will lead to the collapse of ecosystems, with dire consequences for humanity, according to the chief executive of the Environment Agency. Warning that this is not ‚Äúscience fiction‚Äù, Sir James Bevan said on Tuesday that in recent years several of the ‚Äúreasonable worst case scenarios‚Äù had happened in the UK, with more extreme weather and flooding. And he urged politicians to take action to reduce emissions and adapt to the ‚Äúinevitable‚Äù impacts of the climate emergency. Sir James Bevan: ‚ÄòOur thinking needs to change faster than the climate.‚Äô Photograph: House of Commons/PA ‚ÄúMuch higher sea levels will take out most of the world‚Äôs cities, displace millions, and make much of the rest of our land surface uninhabitable or unusable,‚Äù Bevan told the annual conference of the Association of British Insurers. ‚ÄúMuch more extreme weather will kill more people through drought, flooding, wildfires and heatwave

text: When even the @EnvAgency is warning but still the the notion of utter chaos with travel, living and infrastructure doesn‚Äôt even make the TV news and few others outside the @guardian. #climate #carbon #futures https://t.co/YHgRjcPPPh

urls.title: Flood defence force: Helping the Environment Agency stay connected
urls.description: When natural disasters occur, connectivity vital to coordinating relief efforts is often knocked out - that's when Vodafone's emergency response teams can help.

text:
When a natural disaster strikes, emergency services need to have reliable #connectivity to get the work done. üÜò üåä

We are working with The Environment Agency @EnvAgency, part of @DefraGovUK, to support them in such unexpected situations: https://t.co/x600MIwXRT https://t.co/m31zGbelJG

@EnvAgency Welsh Harp Reservoir.
Wembley.
Brent.
Only 6 miles away... https://t.co/0TAcWCaNnX

@Feargal_Sharkey @ben_watt @CanalRiverTrust @EnvAgency @BarnetCouncil @Brent_Council @NaturalEngland I know the welsh harp well and the river Brent, I use to roam the area in the 60s, paddle in the river and catch roach and sticklebacks in nets. This was before Brent Cross. The area was alive with nature. The Harp was never pristine but so much worse now!
